text: hi everyone drama channel here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new conway the
machine record god don't make mistakes
this is a brand new lp from rapper and
buffalo native conway the machine an
important notch in his growing artistic
belt his debut album for eminem's shady
records considering that and the fact
this record has been pushed back a
little bit there's been a lot of
anticipation for it with many fans
including me assuming conway would go
all out for this one and he did but not
in the obvious way that a lot of artists
may for a record like this like of
course there are some big names on this
lp like lil wayne rick ross ti there's
production in the mix from a lot of
griselda mainstays but also hit boy as
well as the alchemist and justice league
but the most striking thing about god
don't make mistakes is how revealing it
is some of the most memorable moments
from conway's last high-water mark from
king to a god were the most
introspective and the machine digs in
even deeper on this lp plus some of the
best crossovers on this thing are either
the most familiar or the most unlikely
of course there's john wu flick with
benny the butcher and west side gun
where they just continue to bring that
next level grimy chemistry and nail that
down in only the way these three guys
can there's also drum work which of
course is named after conway's label and
features more familiar faces j skis and
love the genius and they bring two of
the best features they've done with
conway so far now the extraordinary
talent that is jill scott is featured on
this record too not just with a song but
a wrapped feature which plays the other
side of a love connection being
portrayed on chanel pearls and it's
easily one of the best here like the
flow is great the lyrical detail is
there it locks into the greater
narrative of the song perfectly and when
jill breaks into
those melodic lines on the back end of
her appearance it's like not only
amazing but it's two features in one
keisha plum's intro on the song babis is
surreal and sexual mesmerizing and
conway's mother's vocals are featured on
the final track of the record in in a
way i won't completely uh spoil here but
they are legitimately heart-wrenching
and contribute to a very strong finish
on this lp which thematically ties back
to
a lot of bars and ideas throughout the
rest of the record which makes me have
to point out that god don't make
mistakes is conway's most holistic
project yet in terms of consistency and
vision the intro cut lock load creeps in
with one of the most murderous
instrumentals on the entire lp the
droning synth chords the somewhat mushy
rhythm guitars the first vocals on the
track are conway commenting on how
spooky the vibe is on this one and i
have to agree 100
there's a smoky tone to his voice on
this one like he's trying to keep uh
what he's rapping about a secret which
of course only enhances his entrancing
flow his deadly bars sound like an
endless nightmare and end where a very
complimentary beanie siegel feature
begins now beanie's inclusion on this
track and this record is actually genius
and reinforces the greater themes of
this lp in a lot of ways because beanie
and conway are each victims of gun
violence and in both instances it
impacted their careers and performance
in significant ways that and the violent
horrors being lyrically portrayed on
this track make it almost a mirror of
the closer that sees conway kind of
quietly contemplating what if what if he
had made different choices on that day
that he was shot decided to be in a
different place with a different person
how would things have panned out would
he be where he is today later in the
track list we have piano love which is
pure conway in pretty much every single
way from the creepy fragmented pianos
the fat beats just unadulterated lyrical
nastiness hollow tips having your girl
sneak a gun in for you in her large bag
crack bars that are so detailed they're
almost freaking confessional he said
it's spooky things begin to mellow out
in the tracklist on the song wild
chapters which sees conway reflecting on
the traumatic events and egregious
behavior that he needed to transcend to
get to where he is today he flows so
effortlessly over this track as well in
terms of like narrative and wording it
sounds less like he's rapping less like
a verse and more like a spoken monologue
t.i and novel also do a great job on the
track of reinforcing the songs themes of
personal growth and perseverance a great
hit boy beat on this one too that
features these uh little cycling
melodies quietly playing in the
background like a tune that you would
hum to yourself there's a beautiful
nostalgia to this track that hits really
deep as well which i would say is is
also the case uh for the following
guilty that has all these gorgeous keys
and uh pitched soul chops in the beat
many of the bars on this one read like a
frank meditation on the ways having
gotten shot has infected impacted conway
from the bell's palsy to numbness in his
legs and sort of seeing the comments and
reactions that
that has gotten online and what more can
you say it's like great rapping it's
great performance it's great writing and
conway is delivering with the confidence
and the clarity of like jay-z and his
prime in the mid-2000s they're stressed
which is obviously about stress this is
conway's biggest emotional vent on any
song ever kind of starts off typical in
a way for a rap song working this angle
he's stressed due to the pressure on him
all the attention uh people who are not
really taking his emotions seriously and
asking for handouts left and right but
then very quickly from here we move
deeper into conway coping with a
depression addiction the death of his
son the suicide of his cousin it's
absolutely positively in every way that
it can be
just
devastating if you don't feel for this
guy after this track i don't know what
to tell you like
man the final moments on this lp aren't
all doom and gloom though and in some
ways conway's push to be understood as a
multi-dimensional person on the song so
much more is even more moving as he
demands to not just be pigeonholed as a
rapper or even just a stereotype of a
rapper cause on this track he raps about
his humanity his charity his heart his
perspective which is obviously at this
point in his career really admirable the
ways in which he's been able to geniusly
navigate the music industry to grow his
profile but also maintain an incredible
amount of artistic freedom from here the
luxurious and romantic chanel pearls is
a great change of pace once more that
jill scott features fire and again the
closing track brings things full circle
on this lp in such a powerful way now in
my opinion there are a few weak points
in the track list but i think they're
pretty relative these cuts do have some
decent moments despite some flaws namely
tear gas with lil wayne and rick ross i
think this track features a pretty good
showing lyrically from everybody
involved but everyone's respective
energy just is so
separate and compartmentalized there
isn't really a super strong chorus
bringing it all together either i think
the rick ross verse on the back end
feels almost tacked on after such an
insane verse from wayne again good
production good performances but the
structure isn't the best and i think it
kind of sticks out like a sore thumb
given just how cohesive
narratively and conceptually pretty much
every other song here is especially with
the other features that are in play then
i think the song babas is a bit of a
tough sell as well again while i love
that keisha plum intro it's after that
things begin to trail off with conway i
think trying to
write and deliver in a similarly
fragmented and abstract style with a bit
of a demonic
chorus effect underneath his voice very
subtly and i just don't know if like
this direction is
the best for him it comes off a little
awkward doesn't really reach a strong
conclusion either even though i do love
the fact that this beat is the most
nightmarish and strangest on the entire
lp it's definitely a unique moment you
know you can't say it's a just kind of a
generic spot or just a track that blends
in with everything else and in terms of
the greater album flow it does provide
an interestingly dark pocket just before
this kind of self-affirming finish but
that's kind of it for my complaints
honestly like the vast vast majority of
the material on this lp is
the best conway's ever done he has
outdone himself again his artistry and
vision just continues to grow and i love
it i'm feeling a strong a to a light 9
on this one tran position have you given
this record a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review next hit like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit the bell as well over here next
to my head is another video that you can
